about.title: About NSER
about.description: The National Self-Exclusion Register (NSER) is a groundbreaking initiative designed to help individuals manage their gambling habits.
about.mission_text: To provide a safe, secure, and accessible platform for individuals to voluntarily exclude themselves from gambling services across participating operators.
about.vision_text: A continent where problem gambling is prevented through proactive self-regulation and responsible gaming practices.
about.how_it_works_text: Register your exclusion with NSER, and we'll notify all participating gambling operators. Your exclusion is legally binding.

questions.question: What is the National Self-Exclusion Register?
questions.answer: The NSER is a voluntary, cross-border register that helps individuals exclude themselves from gambling services across participating operators.

questions.question: How does self-exclusion work?
questions.answer: When you register with NSER, we notify participating operators who are required to prevent you from accessing their services during the exclusion period.

questions.question: Is self-exclusion legally binding?
questions.answer: Yes, self-exclusion registered with NSER is legally binding. Operators must comply with the exclusion.

questions.question: Can I lift my self-exclusion early?
questions.answer: Lifting a self-exclusion early depends on the terms you agreed to. Contact NSER support for assistance.

questions.question: Is my information private?
questions.answer: Yes, your personal information is protected and only shared with participating operators who need it to enforce your exclusion.

questions.question: Who should use NSER?
questions.answer: NSER is for anyone who feels they need to control their gambling habits and wants to exclude themselves from gambling services.

questions.question: Which operators participate in NSER?
questions.answer: Many major operators across Africa participate in NSER. Check our operator list for details.

questions.question: How long does exclusion last?
questions.answer: You can choose exclusion periods ranging from 6 months to lifetime exclusion.
